201.description: Account created successfully. Returns access and refresh tokens.

400.description: Invalid input - check email format and password strength

post.description:
Authenticate with your email and password.

Response depends on your account's MFA configuration:

**Case 1: No MFA enabled**
- Immediate response with access and refresh tokens
- Use tokens for all subsequent API requests

**Case 2: MFA enabled (TOTP and/or Passkeys)**
- Response contains a challenge and available MFA methods
- Choose to verify with TOTP code OR passkey
- Send your verification to one of these endpoints:
  - POST /api/auth/mfa/challenges/{challengeId}/totp (for 6-digit code)
  - POST /api/auth/mfa/challenges/{challengeId}/passkey (for passkey)
- After successful MFA, you'll receive your tokens

The challenge remains valid for 5 minutes.

200.description: Login successful (no MFA required). Returns access and refresh tokens.

400.description: Invalid password - weak or same as current password

post.description:
Set up Time-based One-Time Password (TOTP) authentication on your account.

This is the first step to enable TOTP. It generates a secret and returns:
- A QR code URI to scan with your authenticator app
- A challenge ID needed for the next step

Recommended authenticators: Apple Password, Google Authenticator, Microsoft Authenticator.

Next: Scan the QR code or enter the secret in your app, then verify with POST /mfa/totp/verify.

200.description: TOTP setup initiated. Returns QR code URI and secret for backup.

post.description:
Complete TOTP setup by verifying a code from your authenticator app.

After initializing TOTP with POST /mfa/totp/enroll:
1. Scan the QR code in your authenticator app
2. Wait for a 6-digit code to appear
3. Send that code here to activate TOTP

Requirements:
- Valid 6-digit code from your authenticator (changes every 30 seconds)
- Challenge ID from the enrollment step (expires after 10 minutes)
- Must be done within ~1 minute of the code appearing

Once confirmed: TOTP will be required at every login as your second factor.

204.description: TOTP successfully enabled. It will be required for future logins.

401.description: Invalid TOTP code (incorrect 6-digit code) or expired challenge (enrollment expired)

delete.description: Remove TOTP authentication from your account.

get.description: View all passkeys registered to your account.

200.description: Array of all passkeys registered to this account

post.description:
Begin the process of registering a new passkey.

Workflow:
1. Call this endpoint to get WebAuthn registration options
2. Your device will prompt you to authenticate (touch, face, PIN, or button press)
3. Send the response to POST /mfa/passkeys/verify to complete registration

Optional: Give your passkey a friendly name like "Work YubiKey" or "iPhone Face ID" to easily identify it later.

200.description: WebAuthn registration options - ready to use with your authenticator

post.description:
Finalize passkey registration by verifying your authenticator's response.

After calling POST /mfa/passkeys/options and authenticating with your device:
1. Your device provides a signed response
2. Send that response here to register the credential
3. The server verifies it's legitimate and stores your public key

Response: Your updated list of all passkeys including this new one.

201.description: Passkey registered! Returns list of all your passkeys.

400.description: Registration failed - verification error or invalid response

delete.description: Delete a passkey from your account.

post.description:
Finish logging in by providing your 6-digit authenticator code.

When you log in with email/password and TOTP is enabled, you receive a challenge. Complete it by:
1. Finding the 6-digit code in your authenticator app
2. Sending it here with the challenge ID

Success: You'll receive access and refresh tokens to use the API.

200.description: Login successful. Use tokens for API requests.

400.description: TOTP is not enabled for this challenge (challenge requires passkey instead)

401.description: Invalid TOTP code, missing/expired challenge, or TOTP not configured for user

post.description:
Finish logging in by authenticating with your passkey.

When you log in with email/password and passkeys are enabled, you receive a challenge. Complete it by:
1. Using your browser's WebAuthn API with the provided options
2. Authenticating with your device (touch key, biometric, PIN, etc.)
3. Sending the signed assertion response here

Success: You'll receive access and refresh tokens to use the API.

200.description: Login successful. Use tokens for API requests.

400.description: Passkey authentication is not available for this challenge (challenge requires TOTP instead)

401.description: Invalid/unknown passkey, assertion verification failed, or challenge expired/not found

post.description:
Obtain a fresh access token using your refresh token.

Access tokens expire regularly for security. When yours expires, use this endpoint to get a new one without logging in again.

200.description: Token refresh successful. Returns new access token.

info.title: Klardaten Enterprise API
info.description:
The Klardaten Enterprise API offers comprehensive data management capabilities with advanced querying, filtering, and monitoring features.

**Need something simpler?** Our [DATEVconnect Gateway](/docs/gateway) provides basic functionality via DATEVconnect.

### Key Features

- **Advanced Querying**: Pagination, sorting, and field selection for efficient data retrieval
- **Extended Access**: Retrieve data not available via the DATEVconnect API
- **Powerful Filtering**: Complex filter operations with multiple operators and conditions  
- **Complete Webhook Support**: Full Create/Update/Delete notifications including deletions
- **DATEVconnect Access**: All the same DATEV system integration as DATEVconnect Gateway

### Getting Started

Most endpoints require authentication. Here's the basic flow:

1. **Register** or **Login** to get an access token
2. Include the token in all requests: `Authorization: Bearer <your-token>`
3. **Refresh** your token when it expires

#### Quick Example
```http
POST https://api.klardaten.com/api/auth/login
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "email": "your-email@example.com",
  "password": "your-password"
}
```

Response:
```json
{
  "access_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...",
  "refresh_token": "dGhpcyBpcyBhIHJlZnJlc2ggdG9rZW4..."
}
```

Use the `access_token` in subsequent requests:
```http
GET https://api.klardaten.com/api/client-instances
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...
```

### Connecting to DATEV Systems

To access a DATEV system through our API, you need to create a client instance with the consultant number (Beraternummer):

#### 1. Create a Client Instance
```http
POST https://api.klardaten.com/api/client-instances
Authorization: Bearer <your-token>
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "name": "My DATEV instance",
  "consultant_number": "7654321"
}
```

Response:
```json
{
  "id": "48fa2446-c731-4a74-9ea7-b4bd6d66fe5f",
  "name": "My DATEV instance", 
  "consultant_number": "7654321"
}
```

#### 2. Use the Instance ID in Requests
Include the instance ID in the `x-client-instance-id` header for all DATEV-related requests:

```http
GET https://api.klardaten.com/datevconnect/master-data/v1/clients
Authorization: Bearer <your-token>
x-client-instance-id: 48fa2446-c731-4a74-9ea7-b4bd6d66fe5f
```

#### 3. Manage Your Instances
- **List all instances**: `GET /api/client-instances`
- **Get instance details**: `GET /api/client-instances/{instance-id}`

> **Note**: Instance creation can be done before or after installing the Klardaten Connector on your DATEV system.

### Pagination

Our API supports pagination to allow efficient data retrieval, especially when dealing with large datasets. The following query parameters can be used to paginate results:

- **`page`**: The page number to retrieve. Starts at `1`.
- **`page_size`**: The number of items to include in each page. This limits the amount of data returned in a single request. Defaults to `100`.

#### Example
```http
GET https://api.klardaten.com/api/master-data/clients?page=2&page_size=50
```

In the example above, the API returns the second page of client data, with 50 items per page.

Additionally, you can combine pagination with sorting and field filtering using the `order_by` and `fields` parameters:

- **`order_by`**: Sort the data by specified fields in ascending or descending order. For example, to sort by `updated_at` and `client_number` in descending order, use `order_by=updated_at:desc,client_number:desc`.
- **`fields`**: Limit the response to include only specified fields. For instance, use `fields=client_type,client_id` to receive only those fields in the response.

#### Example with Pagination, Sorting, and Field Selection
```http
GET https://api.klardaten.com/api/master-data/clients?page=1&page_size=10&order_by=updated_at:desc,client_number:desc&fields=client_type,client_id
```
In this case, the API returns the first page of 10 clients, sorted by `updated_at` and `client_number` in descending order, and only includes the `client_type` and `client_id` fields in the response.

### Filtering

Filter results using the `filter` query parameter. Multiple filters default to "AND" logic. As an alternative, you can also combine conditions with `OR` and `AND` as well as parentheses inside one single filter expression.

#### Common Operators
| Operator | Description | Example |
|----------|-------------|---------|
| `eq` | Equals | `filter=name eq John` |
| `like` | Contains | `filter=name like Jo` |
| `gt` / `gte` | Greater than (or equal) | `filter=updated_at gte 2024-01-01` |
| `lt` / `lte` | Less than (or equal) | `filter=updated_at lt 2024-12-31` |
| `in` | Matches any value | `filter=status in active, pending` |
| `is` / `isnot` | Null checks | `filter=name isnot null` |

#### Examples
```http
# Single filter
GET /api/master-data/clients?filter=status eq active

# Multiple filters (AND logic)  
GET /api/master-data/clients?filter=status eq active&filter=client_number notin 10000, 10001

# Mixed logic with OR
GET /api/master-data/clients?filter=status eq active OR status eq pending
```

> **Tip**: Check each endpoint's documentation for available filter fields.

### Data Changes Webhooks

Get notified when DATEV data changes. Create webhooks using `POST /api/data-changes/webhooks`.

#### Supported Events
- **Insert/Update**: Receive full object data in `current` field
- **Delete**: Receive object ID in `previous` field (Enterprise API only)

#### Example Payloads
**Insert/Update:**
```json
{
  "id": "55571da2-1223-4b12-bdd4-88e8e38b77aa",
  "instance_id": "2036d556-9b1f-498f-b2e2-0b6d91fa8d73", 
  "timestamp": 1720615358,
  "current": [{ "id": "626029d4-dc00-4f14-9036-2170a5694448", "name": "Franz Camembert", ... }],
  "type": "update"
}
```

**Delete:**
```json
{
  "id": "55571da2-1223-4b12-bdd4-88e8e38b77aa",
  "instance_id": "2036d556-9b1f-498f-b2e2-0b6d91fa8d73",
  "timestamp": 1720615358, 
  "previous": [{ "id": "626029d4-dc00-4f14-9036-2170a5694448" }],
  "type": "delete"
}
```

#### Supported Entities
- `client`
- `document` 
- `document-structure-item`


### Webhook Delivery and Retry Logic

When a webhook event occurs, our system sends a webhook to the specified endpoint. If the webhook delivery fails, our system implements a retry mechanism to ensure successful delivery.

#### Key Features of Webhook Retry Logic:

- **Automatic Retries**: If the webhook delivery fails (due to a non-2xx response or a timeout), the system will automatically retry.
- **Exponential Backoff**: The retry intervals increase exponentially after each failed attempt, starting with a 1-second delay for the first retry, doubling with each subsequent retry (e.g., 1s, 2s, 4s, etc.).
- **Max Retry Attempts**: By default, the system will retry up to 10 times. If all retries fail, the webhook delivery will be marked as failed, and the issue will be logged.
- **Timeout Management**: Each webhook attempt is given a maximum of 15 seconds to complete. If no response is received within that time, the attempt will be considered failed.
- **Failure Logging**: Each failed attempt is logged, and after all retries are exhausted, a final failure report will be created.

### Verifying Webhooks Authenticity

We provide an additional security measure to verify the webhooks you receive are genuine. This can be useful if you're looking to ensure only Klardaten webhooks are being made to your endpoint and ensure the information is genuine and as the system expects. These signatures will also help prevent against replay attacks. Verifying the signing secret is optional.

Webhook requests will contain a header which can be used to verify the request's authenticity: `x-klardaten-webhook-signature`. This is used in conjunction with the payload of the request.

#### Getting a Webhook's Secret

When creating a new webhook, a `secret` property will be returned along with the webhook's details.

You should store this secret at your end if you are interested in verifying our webhooks signatures.

#### Verifying the Signature

To verify the webhook signature sent as the `x-klardaten-webhook-signature` header, you should sign the request's body with the webhook secret key using SHA256, then generate a hexadecimal digest, which can be represented as `hexdigest(HMACSHA256(BODY))`.

#### Verification Example (Node.js)

```javascript
const crypto = require("crypto");

function verifyWebhookSignature(body, signature, secret) {
  const hmac = crypto.createHmac('sha256', secret);
  const computedSignature = hmac
    .update(Buffer.from(JSON.stringify(body), 'utf8'))
    .digest('hex');
  
  return computedSignature === signature;
}

// Usage in your webhook handler
const isValid = verifyWebhookSignature(
  req.body, 
  req.headers["x-klardaten-webhook-signature"], 
  "your-webhook-secret"
);
```

### Request Correlation ID

To help with tracking and debugging, our API supports a correlation id mechanism. This allows both the client and server to uniquely identify and trace each request.

How It Works:

- **Client-Supplied Correlation ID**: You can include an optional X-Correlation-Id header in your requests. This ID will be included in the response headers as well, making it easy to track the request across different services or when reporting issues.
- **Auto-Generated Correlation ID**: If you don't provide a X-Correlation-Id in your request, our API will generate a unique correlation id for you and include it in the response headers.
- **Error Reporting**: The Correlation ID is also logged with any errors, making it easy to reference and investigate specific issues. Clients can use this ID when reporting problems, allowing for more efficient troubleshooting.

#### Example

Here's how you can include a X-Correlation-Id in your requests:

```http
GET https://api.klardaten.com/api/client-instances
Authorization: Bearer ey...
X-Correlation-Id: 123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000
```

In this example, the server will return the same X-Correlation-Id in the response:

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
X-Correlation-Id: 123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000
```

* `GESPENS`: Former partner/legal successor with pension entitlement - Ehemaliger Gesellschafter/Rechtsnachfolger mit Pensionsanspruch
